div1.p: Redd has little additional information to give Hench about Henry Rose Carter.

div1.head: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, December 19, 1947
div1.opener:
December 19th, 1947
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have just received your letter of December 9th in
regard to Dr. Walter Reed's work in yellow fever.

I can add but very little to what I have written you,
mainly because the information I have is from conversations with
my uncle, Dr. Henry Rose Carter, who died in September 1925 in
Washington, D. C.

After Dr. Carter's work in malaria, he and Walter Reed
began work along the same line to discover the yellow fever
carrier. They had mapped out a line of work and experimentation.
An epidemic of yellow fever broke out along the south Atlantic
and Gulf Coast and Dr. Carter was put in charge of quarantine
and whatever health measures he thought proper. Reed continued
with his experiments and I think the letter written by Dr. Reed
to Dr. Carter, a copy of which I sent you, shows the result of
Dr. Reed's work.

Dr. Carter wrote a treaties on the history of yellow
fever etc. for the Rockefeller Foundation after he had been
incapacitated as assistant surgeon general in public health
work; most of his work being done while confined to his bed,
his daughter, Laura A. Carter, who later married Admiral
Stitht, being his secretary, and knew his work I expect better
than anyone else, and did a great deal of the research work
for him. She is now also dead. I think Admiral Stitht could
give you a good deal of information. Dr. Carter has one son,
Dr. Henry Rose Carter, 805 Woodward Building, Birmingham,
Alabama. His wife, Dr. Melson Barfield Carter, is at the
head of the x-ray work for the University of Alabama and in
charge of that work at the hospital in Birmingham. They may
be able to give you further information.

Dr. Henry Rose Carter, Sr. disliked publicity and would
not allow interviews with newspaper reporters. Dr. Carter
spent some time in Peru and in Colombia and I think parts of
Chile, making investigations for the Rockefeller Foundation
and it is probable that some of his work there may be
connected with Reed's work, though I do not know about this
as it may be that Reed died before Dr. Carter went to South
America.

I have heard Dr. Lazear's name mentioned by Dr. Carter
and his daughter, but I do not recollect the details in regard
to him.

If I run across anything which I think may be of
interest to you, I will let you hear from me again. There are
several boxes of letters stored in Ashland, Virginia. I will
endeavor to look through these as I find time and as I say, if
I find anything that may be of interest to you, I will be glad
to write you.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, H. Carter Redd HCR: jh
